choices: to separate the sheep from the cattle.
to shop the dingoes from being slaughtered by farmers.
to protect the Australian wool industry.
to act as a boundary between properties.

question: According to the writer, why was the fence built?

text: A war has been going on for almost a hundred years between the sheep farmers of Australia and the dingo, Australia’s wild dog. To protect their livelihood, the farmers built a wire fence, 3,307 miles of continuous wire mesh, reaching from the coast of South Australia all the way to the cotton fields of eastern Queensland, just short of the Pacific Ocean. The Fence is Australia’s version of the Great Wall of China, but even longer, erected to keep out hostile invaders, in this case hordes of yellow dogs.
